instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMC’s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message:
Hey guys, I have this rabbit hole of a liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B board I'm working on. Initially, I started out replacing <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> -- it was so burnt, it basically fell off the board. Also, the board had a couple broken paths by traces I was able to repair easily by <CAPACITOR>C5001</CAPACITOR>/L5001 (TP[1]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL>), and <CAPACITOR>C7503</CAPACITOR> to TP[1]<SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREG3</SIGNAL> by <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>. Both of these areas were visibly corroded, and besides some semi-burnt looking trace points, which I checked for continuity (they passed), these seem to be the only issues I can visibly detect after many sweeps of the board.

When I started with this board there was no light of any kind. I went through the rails, and decided to replace <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, which restored charger light. Moving on, I decided to replace <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, because of its proximity to <CAPACITOR>C7503</CAPACITOR>/TP[1]<SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREG3</SIGNAL> and because of heavy corrosion in that area. However, I'm reading 0.0 voltage on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, and for some reason <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is reading 0.2V. Consequently, Pin 4 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is only reading 0.2V (I think it's supposed to be ~3.4), which I believe is causing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> to not generate .

Additionally, after measuring all my power rails for shorts, I discovered a fluctuating short on <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL> (the short is usually 38Ohms, but sometimes it goes to 80Ohms or 100Ohms, and occasionally it reads a solid 90Ohms on the meter, while beeping at me like morse code). Weirdly enough, the voltage I read on <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 3.34V. I've actually gone through every component on the board which is connected to the rail, and nothing visibly jumped out as a shorted component. However, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> are NOT showing a short -- this is an area where I repaired a broken path and replaced <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>. Thinking the short could possibly be in the SMC, and because I couldn't figure out how those two relate to <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, I decided to reflow the SMC, however no voltages changed.

The relevant voltages on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> read as following:
Pin 4 - 0.2V
Pin 21 - 3.419V
Pin 12 - 3.419V

Pin 3 - 1.254V
Pin 13 - 2.006V (Is this right? Isn't it supposed to be ~3.3V, or is that only after <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>?)
Pin 23 - 8.63V
Pin 29 - 5.05V
Pin 22 - 3.314V
Pin 14 - 5.05V
Pin 12 - 3.419V
Pin 24 - 3.459V
Pin 2 - 0.0V

Anyway, I've hit the wall on this one, and it's to the point where I HAVE to fix it, just for the principle of it. Any advice is appreciated. Let me know if you need any other voltages.

Edit: Also, I did an SMC reset, and the charger turned green and then back to orange.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message:
"Pin 13 - 2.006V (Is this right? Isn't it supposed to be ~3.3V, or is that only after <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>?)"
Is named VREF2, guess why?

"fluctuating short on <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL> (the short is usually 38Ohms, but sometimes it goes to 80Ohms or 100Ohms, and occasionally it reads a solid 90Ohms on the meter"
Hope you didn't measure with the board powered on.
Allow 20s after removing power, before measure resistance to ground; to discharge any residual tension.

Are you using original charger?
Post <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> signals.
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is correct?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 15949"]"Pin 13 - 2.006V (Is this right? Isn't it supposed to be ~3.3V, or is that only after <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>?)"
Is named VREF2, guess why?[/QUOTE] 
Ya, I just figured since the line is called P3V3, it should be ~3.3V -- so 2.005 is correct?

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 15949"]"fluctuating short on <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL> (the short is usually 38Ohms, but sometimes it goes to 80Ohms or 100Ohms, and occasionally it reads a solid 90Ohms on the meter"
Hope you didn't measure with the board powered on.
Allow 20s after removing power, before measure resistance to ground; to discharge any residual tension.[/QUOTE] 
Unless I'm derping out, I always unplug when I measure resistances/shorts.  I won't say I wait 20s, but I do wait, and yes the short is present without power.  

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 15949"]Are you using original charger?[/QUOTE] I am using an original 14.85V charger.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 15949"]Post <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> signals.
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is correct?[/QUOTE]
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 0.0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> = 0.0V
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.392V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message:
VREF2 means 2V refference voltage; so is correct.

PCH will not start the board untill <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> goes high.
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> should be high too.
Check <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWRMEN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
Also check PCH's RTC signals.
Both SMC and PCH receive correct 32KHz clock?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 15952"]VREF2 means 2V refference voltage; so is correct.[/quote] Gotcha, thanks for that!

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 15952"]PCH will not start the board untill <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> goes high.
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> should be high too.[/QUOTE] <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> is reading 1.042V.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 15952"]Check <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWRMEN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
Also check PCH's RTC signals.[/QUOTE]
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 3.248V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.418V

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 15952"]Both SMC and PCH receive correct 32KHz clock?
[/QUOTE] I don't currently have an oscilloscope, so I can't check the frequency.  :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> is too low.
You can check clock signal presence "aproximatelly" in DC voltage scale; this cannot confirm 100% correct signal.
Normally should read 0.45V for PCH and 1.7V for SMC side.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message: So far the basics have not even been measured. Voltage on PPBUS and L7560? Corrosion under SMC is also likely.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 15958"]<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> is too low.[/QUOTE]
Ok, I just measured <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> again and now it's reading 3.39V -- not sure what happened there. I doubled checked the resistor, and it's showing about 10k and there's no short there.


[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 15958"]You can check clock signal presence "aproximatelly" in DC voltage scale; this cannot confirm 100% correct signal.
Normally should read 0.45V for PCH and 1.7V for SMC side.[/QUOTE]
Pin 12 on <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> = .426V
Pin 2 on <RESISTOR>R5112</RESISTOR> (for <SIGNAL>SMC_CLK32K</SIGNAL>) = .395V -- so I'm guessing CPU isn't generating it correctly for some reason?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 15964"]So far the basics have not even been measured. Voltage on PPBUS and L7560? Corrosion under SMC is also likely.[/QUOTE]

L7560 = 3.345V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.62V on both sides of the board.  

I did reflow the SMC, but that doesn't rule out a bad pad or bad SMC -- which would be unfortunate.  There was corrosion around some SMC components and on that side of the board, though.  Been waiting on my Crest for quite a while, or I would have already given this sucker a bath.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message: Probably crap under the SMC or more corroded resistors/traces around it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 15973"]Probably crap under the SMC or more corroded resistors/traces around it.[/QUOTE]

Hoping I finally get my Crest this week -- derps sent me a basket, but no cleaner :D . I'll run it through that, and see what it does. After that I might take the SMC off and see what's going on underneath -- hopefully the pads are still there.

That said, shouldn't <SIGNAL>SMC_CLK32K</SIGNAL> be showing the right amount of voltage on <RESISTOR>R5112</RESISTOR>, or could an SMC short be pulling that down? Also, is it possible any of this is caused by that weird short on <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL> that doesn't effect the voltage, or could the SMC cause that as well?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message: That weird short is no short. You are measuring with power applied or don't wait long enough for power to discharge.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 15978"]That weird short is no short. You are measuring with power applied or don't wait long enough for power to discharge.[/QUOTE]

I know -- it's super weird, but I never do short or resistance measurements with power applied.  I actually went through every single connection on the <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL> line, which was over 50 measurements on both sides of the board -- no power attached -- and the drop to ground was steady on every component in the line.  I can't believe the residual charge in the line would have stayed the entire time it took for me to measure 50 connections.  

I know it sounds crazy, haha.

threads.message:

Also, is it possible any of this is caused by that weird short on <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL> that doesn't effect the voltage, or could the SMC cause that as well?[/QUOTE]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 15978"]That weird short is no short. You are measuring with power applied or don't wait long enough for power to discharge.[/QUOTE]

I just left the board unplugged overnight, and I'm still measuring a 55Ohm short to ground on <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.  With resistance that low, shouldn't the rail be a fraction of what it should be?



[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 15982"]

you must be either tommy or colin. expect something to arrive by tuesday-wednesday latest![/QUOTE]

Good guess!  If their cleaners weren't so favorably reviewed, I probably would have tried to get something else, but I'm willing to wait for the best.  Thanks for all your help on it, Louis.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message:
055 is not a short!
Multimeter buzzer sounds till 070, that doesn't mean short...
Measure inverting probe leads too; normally get different readings.
At this moment, does your board try to start at least; with charger, battery, or both?

P.S. Ivy Bridge core has 001 as normal value; do you consider that a short???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B -- No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>, 0.2V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> -- Green to solid orange light
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 15999"]055 is not a short!
Multimeter buzzer sounds till 070, that doesn't mean short...
Measure inverting probe leads too; normally get different readings.[/QUOTE]
Ah, ok that's some good info to have.  That measurement has had me scratching my head for a bit.  I'm just getting started out, so I thought anything that didn't read 0L was passing current to ground.  When is it considered a short, then?  Does that just come with more experience with certain rails, or is there some baseline you would look for?  Also, does that mean a connection to ground is built into the rail somewhere?  I measure with red on ground and black on the lead.  

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 15999"]
At this moment, does your board try to start at least; with charger, battery, or both?[/QUOTE]
No fan spin. Just orange light on charger.

<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> isn't getting the proper voltage on pin 4, because the sleep signals aren't present.  So <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> isn't generating.

Thanks for the help so far!
